item.description:
Prairie Aflame!
The Northwest Rebellion of 1885

This game is an operational treatment of Canada's Northwest Rebellion of 1885. The Metis (half Native and half European) set up a provisional government to try and get recognition of their concerns with the federal government in Ottawa.

The federal government orders a detachment of Mounties to confiscate any weapons located at the Metis settlement of Duck Lake. The Mounties were met by a force of Metis and Natives and initially there was just talk. However, during the course of the discussion a gun was discharged and within minutes, the battle was on! The Mounties retreated, having taken 25% casualties - the rebellion was on.

To prevent the rebellion from spreading, the government in Ottawa quickly dispatches a military force which would grow to 5,000 troops, most transported by the nearly complete Canadian Pacific Railway. After 4 months and several battles later, the government had successfully suppressed the rebellion - if they had not, and this was their worst fear, the whole Northwest might have erupted in rebellion, keeping the government busy for years.

The basic military unit in the game is the battalion. All the battalions that participated in the campaign are represented, as are the various Northwest Mounted Police detachments, local militias, artillery, and Gatling guns. They are faced by the Metis, the Woods Cree, and the Plains Cree. Units can remain together as battalions, or they can break down. Morale is better as a battalion, while mobility is better as a breakdown unit. Each strength point represents 50 men. The main rebel and government leaders are represented and they have an important effect on the game.

The map shows the area of the Prairies in Canada from Edmonton and Calgary in the west to QuíAppelle in the east. Map scale is 11 miles to the hex, and each turn represents one week. The map is 22 x 34. There is also a 24 page rulebook, and a number of charts, tables, and organizational sheets as well.
 Game scale
Unit sizes:
Battalion
1 Strength Point = 50 men
Each hex equals 11 Miles across.
Each game turn represents one week.

The game where players let it all hang out! Which 3 of the Seven Dwarfs are most like me? Who are my 3 heroes? Players write answers they think others will write on their wipe off board. If they know their friend well, their answers will match and they collect socks from the laundry basket. Whoever forms the most sock pairs wins!

name.value: Grandmama's Improved Game of Useful Knowledge

item.description:
From "The Games we Played".
Early McLoughlin Brothers game where players assume the role of Scholars and designate one participant to act as "preceptor". Scholars test their knowledge by answering questions posed on cards, and the preceptor confirms or corrects them after consulting companion book of answers.
Peanut Gallery -- the new fast-paced talking game. Pull a trivia card and quickly convince your friends of your answer and you can win!

Pickel the Pirate, A Treasure Map to Knowledge, is a board game that teaches while it entertains. Let's find the treasure of knowledge together!

With each roll of the die, you'll make your way through the treasure map where you can win a treasure, lose a treasure, or just have fun learning along the way. Categories include math, spelling, rhymes, time, the alphabet, and things about your friends.

From Wizards' website:

Based on the film releasing July 4th, with additional favorites from TRANSFORMERS history, the TRANSFORMERS 3D battle-card game lets you take total control of your favorite AUTOBOT and DECEPTICON characters! Crack open a pack and start building your 'bots. Or, build them in their vehicle form using the same set of pieces! Once you've assembled your characters, battle away, because even though they're fun to put together, they're even more fun to play with!

Each battle pack comes with four randomly inserted constructible cards (enough to build two characters), two stat cards containing character and battle information, a token card, and game rules with assembly diagrams.

item.description:
Print-and-play game featured in the webcomic Userfriendly.org. Included in three consecutive Sunday comics from April 15-29, 2007.

Each player takes on the role of a character from the comic strip, attempting to collect the items listed on the player's character card and return them to the character's desk. Certain items with special powers and several non-player character tokens can aid or hinder the players.

How much do you remember about famous sporting moments?
Just like the original "Reminiscing" Master Game Edition that 1000's have enjoyed for over a decade, this special sports edition will not only challenge your lifetime memories of watching sports, but will also stimulate you to share thoughts and feelings from your own personal past.

This "Reminiscing" will take you on a nostalgic journey through the great sporting moments of the 1940's to today.

"Inwigilacja" is a game about politicians, who are trying to win support for their parties. They do this by unmasking the opponents' scandals. "Inwigilacja" is a deduction game, similar to "The mystery of the Abbey", it is a heavy satire on Polish parliament and government.

The game contains the following components:

- the deck of 54 files cards
- the deck of 45 action cards
- 10 answer cards
- 10 pawns
- 5 locations
- 1 poll results (victory) track
- 1 die
- notebooks
- the rulebook

[From the Publisher:] The Nurturing Game teaches adults and children to express their feelings, to become aware of themselves and others, to use their personal power in positive ways, to praise, to use gentle touch, and to get along with others.
Animals, the earth, and the elements have been portrayed on the game board as symbolic of a world where despite size, color, and capabilities, everyone and everything is accepted.
The goal of the nurturing game is to begin along the two tracks that lead children and adults to a world of hugs, togetherness and rainbows. Along the way, players will get a chance to express their feelings, increase their self awareness, learn to use their personal power in positive ways, practice using gentle touch, and offer words of praise to themselves and others. The game ends when everyone meets at the rainbow.

A prime mechanism of Roman expansion and control in the provinces was the municipium (pronounced MU-ni-KIP-ee-um), the premiere Roman provincial town. Being granted the status of a municipium brought a town into the Roman orbit and involved both duties to Rome and a gradual extension of the Roman citizenship to the inhabitants.

This game takes place in one of these municipalities in a western province. The time is the middle of the 2nd Century AD, when the Empire had reached its greatest territorial extent and was enjoying its longest period of imperial peace.

Players are each in control of a powerful family and try to strategically place their family members in the various institutions throughout the municipium and gain the support of the citizens: Scholars, Merchants, Soldiers, and Priests. At various times during the game, if a player has the most influence in an institution, the player can exert the power of that institution and gain the support of certain citizens. Meanwhile, the praefect moves around the municipium and players strive to have the most influence in the institutions that he visits, thereby earning his favour. Each of these institutions have unique powers, and players must decide how and when to use them. The player best utilizing their power will become the most influential family in the municipium.

Municipium is #2 in the Valley Games Modern Line

item.description:
The premise here is that all of the players are Knights working together to build three new towers before King Duncan returns home to his castle.

Unfortunately, your only building tool is a bizarre device made of satin cord, wooden balls, and what appears to be an elastic ponytail holder. (Clearly, the material culture of the Middle Ages is full of surprises!) You use this device to pick up, move, and deposit various building blocks and the wooden figures of the Prince, the Princess, and the Ghost who top the towers.

Which towers you are required to build (i.e. what blocks in what order) are determined by drawing cards. If you succeed in constructing the tower illustrated before the timer runs out, then you keep that card. If you fail, King Duncan moves forward one space. Collect three cards before he gets to the castle and you win.

Ages 5 and up.

item.description:
Jetan-Sarang is a chess-like game, played on a 12x12 board. The designer was inspired by the Martian tales by Edgar Rice Burroughs, but Sarang differs from the Jetan game described in ERB's Chessmen of Mars.

Rules and photographs of the game can be found on the designer's website:

http://www.sprattart.com/cgi-bin/details.pl?idno=410

The game Tactica "S" is a deep abstract game for two players. It has 8 white pieces and 8 black pieces that move along an 8x8 board.

The mechanics are similar to Chess (the movement of pieces), Tablut (the way pieces capture other pieces) and Othello (pieces change sides - colours).

Pieces are never removed from board, but only change sides. The winner is the one who captures or blocks all the opponents pieces.

One of many local variations on the boardgame Monopoly, Sonopoly is based on Sonoma County, California. Produced by Santa Rosa-based Trinity Productions in 1985, it was assembled by Rapid Mounting and Finishing Co. of Burlingame, California.

The mechanics, most rules, board, and themes are mostly the same as Monopoly, but there are some significant differences.

Board and Properties: The properties are all businesses in Sonoma County; there are no railroads or utilities; there are no jail, free-parking, or go-to-jail spaces; there are chance cards, but no community chest or equivalent; all four corners are properties which players can buy and on which they must pay rent; the purchase prices and rent are all different.

Rules: There are coloured monopolies essentially the same as in Monopoly, but in addition, the four corners together make up one monopoly just like properties of one colour. Players build "investments" instead of houses and can build up to 2 on each property. The few non-coloured properties not at the corners are stand-alone properties on which one can build an investment without owning any other properties. Finally, players collect $2,000 not for passing "go" but for passing the West America Bank space (at the location of the go-to-jail space in Monopoly).

Pieces: Money is in demoninations of $20, 50, 100, 500, 1000, and 5000. Each amount has a different business and picture on it. The player pieces are coloured plastic pawns. The investment pieces are not houses and hotels, but coloured wooden cylinders called "barrels" in the rules.

Horror in a Small Town. An enchanted camera has drawn you into an ever-shifting nightmare. Your only hope of escape is to maneuver the other players to their deaths before they do the same to you!

HeroCard Nightmare is a surreal psychological thriller in which the last surviving dreamer wins. Nightmare blends deductive, clue-like gameplay with fast-paced HeroCard dueling, and sets them inside a modular, ever-changing landscape of gothic horror.

Nightmare is a HeroCard game, and comes complete with four HeroDecks. Nightmare does not have any expansion decks, as all four characters come complete within the Nightmare box.

Nightmare is compatible with all the other HeroCard games.

item.description:
From the box:

This magnetic game with colour-changing pieces puts your logic and memory to test!

The special SATA pieces each contain four different colours. Depending on which space and orientation they are placed in on the SATA board, a different colour will be displayed in the window. The object of the game is to make a “triad” – a straight line of three SATA pieces in a row that show the same colour in their windows. This is not as easy as it sounds, since each time you move or twist a piece, its colour changes.

Learning to play SATA is very simple – but to become a SATA Master you will need to learn the patterns behind the colour changes. SATA is a captivating logic game for everyone aged 7+!

Contents: SATA board with 3 score markers, 8 SATA pieces and rules.
The pieces are stored in the flip-down sides of the board.

The game board folds out from a double LP put out by 93 / KHJ, a radio station. The name of the album is "Sound of the Sixties". Instructions are printed on the inside of the record sleeve.

It's a basic roll and move game, utilizing a spinner, along with "Blooper" and "Ad Lib" cards that are drawn after landing on certain spaces of the board. The theme centers around the particular DJs of that era and station, and each player chooses their favorite DJ token to represent them while moving around the board. The goal is to become Disc Jockey of the Year.

The game is set in California, with locations like Malibu and Disneyland, and the spaces allude to various radio station activities, such as "Commercial Break", "On the Air", and "You Get Beatles Exclusive".

name.value: Kas atsirado anksčiau? Višta ar kiaušinis?
Was war zuerst da? Huhn oder Ei?

item.description: Chicken or Egg is a trivia game in which players land on different categories on the board and must answer a trivia question from that category. The questions are all "which came first?". Eg. Which came first Peanut Butter or Jelly. To win the game a player or team must be the first to win a card from each of the six categories and make it the the center of the board.

An obscure board game take on Formula One released by small games publisher Actiongable during the late 70's. Gear Shift has a unique and in many ways quite realistic take on F1 racing, where the movements are generally dictated not by dice, but by on-track position.

So - unusually for a car-racing board game - this is very much a strategy game, with the element of chance coming in the form of hazard squares which require a roll from the 36-item hazard list on the inside of the box lid.

Only one track comes with the game - Brands Hatch - but the rule book claims that Actiongable were going to make further tracks available. One can only assume that disappointing sales scuppered those plans.

A hidden gem of the genre.

A simple Formula One racing game released by the electronics manufacturer Siemens for their Formula 1 sponsorship program.

Simple and basic system with few if any nods to realism, strategy or playability.

In this game, players are traveling around the world and score points by visiting various places around the world. The goal is to visit at least five different continents and return home, but even though the first player to complete his journey gets a points bonus, other players can still win by visiting more places.


Travel to all the continents... Europe, North America, South America, Africa, Asia and Australia to get points along the way

An exciting tactic game for 2-4 players in from 6 and above.

The game board is a map of the world, devided into 286 squares (13x22). One (1) square is red with a big white S, six (6) of the squares are red with a white number - there is one on each continent. The 24 squares have a white circle with a number on (10, 20, 25, 30 or 50).

Before the game all the "white" spaces gets a blue token on, with the consistent number of the field; this will leave 10 tokens of each 10 points in spare, which is put aside together with the red "proof tokens".

All players start on "S" which is located on a field which have Iceland to the west, England to the south and Norway to the east.
The players take turns by rollin the die (D6) and move the amount that the die shows. They can move North, South, East or West (not diagonally) and can move in zig-zig (Example on the roll 5: North, West, North, West, South). A player can not move into or pass a square where another player is on.
When a player lands on either a point-field (white circle with red numbers) the player takes the point on the board, if it have not been taken before. If a player lands on one of the red fields on each continent, the player can take the matching number from the pool if (s)he do not have this number yet. The red "proof tokens" are put infront of the player, visible for everone.
Each time you pass Equator you get 10 points from the pool, as long as there are still points left to take.

When you have at least fice (5) of the six (6) "proof tokens", you can move back to the "S" , and this will give you 100 points.
Second one back to base get's 50, third gets 25 and the last don't get any points for returnin. When everyone is back you add the points (Home-coming, red tokens (75 points each) and blue tokens (10-50 points each). The player with the highest score is the winner.

From the rules sheet:
The object of Go Diamond is to be the first person to accomplish and maintain all of the following:
Completely fill in the Organization Chart that each player has with People Chips. 
Reach the 7500 level on the Go Diamond ladder with second pawn.
Acquire and keep one Dream Card from each of the three separate color-coded Dream categories.

item.description:
A crime wave hits the city. The police round up the usual suspects: including you. In order to escape prison, you’ll have to accuse your fellow criminals of the crimes under investigation.

Criminals is a psychological party card game for 3-9 players, in the style of such games as Werewolf and The Resistance, from the game design team of Origins Award-winning and Spiel Des Jahres-recommended game designer Kory Heath (Zendo, Why Did The Chickenâ€¦?, Blockers) and Origins Award-winning and Ennie Award-winning game designer Dave Chalker (Get Bit!)

Each player is dealt a crime, with an extra crime belonging to the mysterious Crime Boss. Each round, a random crime will come up under investigation. Interrogate and accuse each other to try to figure out who is guilty of the crime, or if it could be the Crime Boss. If you are accused and are guilty, you’re eliminated from the game. If you have an alibi for the crime, you’re given the chance to try and snitch on who you think committed the crime. If you’re snitch correctly, you win, but otherwise, you’re eliminated. The game ends when someone snitches correctly, all but one player are eliminated, or if anyone is brave enough to try and confront the Crime Boss with his crime.

Criminals is an update/re-release of the original version from 2007. This edition of Criminals features improved game play, heavy development and playtesting, refined rules, and new graphic design of full color cards.

item.description: Board game based on the 20th Century Fox film "Independence Day"

A children's roll and move game combined with a touch of dexterity.

The game board is a huge ladder, the playing pieces are little men carrying sacks on their backs. Each player has four of these with four different sack colors. Driven by dice, these men walk up (and occasionally down) the ladder, trying to reach the top. When three men stand on the same rung, though, the rung topples and all the men fall down, bringing down all those below them, too.

The object of the game is to gather cards into sets representing historical conflicts that involved the United States.

The thirty-six cards are divided into six "suits" designated by the following flags: American, English, English Naval, Spanish, Mexican, and Tripolitan. The cards contain questions related to the following wars: the American Revolution, War with the Barbary Pirates, War of 1812, Mexican War, U.S. Civil War, and the Spanish-American War. The instructions are printed on the underside of the box lid.

Players acquire cards from other players by correctly answering questions on the cards.

From Box Back:

"Two players can take part in the game the object of which is to be the first to complete the puzzle. Outwit is a fast, challenging game where the perception, imagination and intelligence of each player is tested.

"The box contains 2 plastic boards, 16 big plastic pieces of various geometrical shapes, 4 rectangular pieces and 12 small square pieces.

"Each player attempts to solve the puzzle by trying to fit a chosen set of geometrical shapes on to his/her board without moving any of the existing pieces placed by their opponent.

"The winner is the first person to correctly fill all the gaps with the geometrical shapes."

Bank “O” La is a clever game that teaches children to count—and save—money. Each player begins the game with dimes, nickels, and a quarter, for a total of $1.00. Players select their piggy bank, place their money in their pocket space on the board, and roll the die to begin moving clockwise around the bright, colorful game board.

As you move around the board, you take turns purchasing items from the vending machine, taking money from someone else’s pocket, putting money in someone’s pocket, or placing money in your piggy bank. Money changes hands many times from either the vending machine or another player, forcing players to keep a good account of their funds.

The ever-popular Spider-Man is back! Based on the movie, Spider-Man 3 combats foes and villains in New York City!

Capture as many villains as you can to help spider-Man win the battle within! Play cards to capture villains or liberate your opponents' bad guys.

The Battle Within Game could fairly be described as a deluxe edition of the Spider-Man Crime Stopper Card Game, adding a game board, but keeping the same gameplay. For ages 6 and up and comes with 50 collectible cards.

item.description:
Players will travel by the world, passing by the five localities indicated in a card of selected trip at random and returning to the departure point, a Spanish city chosen by the own player.

Every player gets some money and his travel card. He can choose between road, ship and plane routes to get his destinations and every kind of transportation costs different (100, 500, 5000). A road travel rolls half of a six dice roll. A ship travel rolls one six dice. A plane travel rolls two six dices.

At every destination city, players must stay one turn and buying a postal card for 500.

Contents are a board depicting the whole world and routes, 65 postal cards, 13 travel cards, 6 pawns, 2 dices and money.

POD stands for "Power Of Direction."

A chess-like game, in that there are pieces with different movement rules moving around a square-grid board. Each player has a "king" (the Communication and Command Pod, or C.C.P.) that must be captured for the opponent to win. The board is 15-by-15 squares, divided into 9 5x5 sections. And there is a repeating pattern of walls that restrict movement. The basic movement mechanic is that each piece (individually called "Pods") moves a given number of segments, called "Direction Changes" or D.C.'s. For example, a piece with 3 D.C.'s could move forward as many spaces as it wants (subject to walls of course), then left as many spaces as it wants, and then forward again. Pods must move their entire number of D.C.'s without backtracking.

In addition to the basic movement mechanic of D.C.'s, many of the pieces have additional movement abilities, such as the Jump Pod (J.P.) that can jump over one piece during its movement, or the Variable Direction Change Pod (V.D.C.P.) which has a choice as to how many D.C.'s it may make when it moves.

There is a basic game (nine pods), and an advanced version which adds four more pods. They give an even more advanced version (which they call "POD Pinnacle") in which the nine board parts are set up in a non-standard way. You can also combine two sets together for a four-player game (assuming the pieces are of four different colors), and presumably, you could combine even more sets together for as many players as you want, as long as you have some means of distinguishing each player's pieces from the others.

Slahal (pronounced sle -`hal) is an indigenous very old, Pacific Coast Indian Gambling Game. The game is also called the "bone game", "stick game" or "hand game" and is still played today by many in the Northwest. It is played, either as a two player game or as a team game. It originally used small pieces of animal bone as game pieces but now many kinds of substances have replaced those bones. Pieces of antler having both a rounded side and a flat side were used while a grouping of separate sticks serve as the score keeping method. Each team begins with a set number of scoring sticks. The two game pieces (acting almost like dice) are picked up by a player and secretly arranged on a flat surface. This is done to the accompaniment of Native Music. The object of the game is to correctly guess where certain game bones are located in the opponents hand. During the playing of the music the pieces are arranged in different patterns, either both flat pieces down, both round pieces down or 1 going each way so that there are 4 possible combinations that can be accomplished. The opponent or the leader of the opposing team will motion to the other leader that they are ready to guess the direction of the unmarked bones. He uses a set of hand signals to make his guess. Each time he guesses incorrectly, he must throw one of his score keeping sticks to the opposing team. The team that eventually wins all of the opponents score keeping sticks wins the match

Nothing in this description was intentionally taken from the Elliott Avedon Museum & Archive of Games, a public funded Museum in Canada who would not give permission for the Museum's description of the game to be used. This compilation is taken from numerous other sources found.

This game was re-created by Bill Kuhnely in 1981.
A Simple spin and move game for children, where each player tries to move his kittens around the track and back into the home area. Based on the nursery rhyme of the same name.

[from back of box]

The "City by the Bay takes pride in being a place for all seasons, where there is fun for all ages, all year round. Thunder Bay is unique, rich in character and culture - recently named Canada's Cultural Capital. Nature and history have formed many of our traditional tourist attractions, but there are still plenty of secret places and undiscovered highlights to explore.

Honey Springs is a DTP game by LPD Games, designed as a mini-game introduction to their Battles of the American Civil War series. Honey Springs covers the largest Civil War battle in the Indian Nations and features major Indian forces on both sides, and the 1st Kansas Colored Volunteers, the West's premier Black regiment.

DTP Components are downloadable PDF's.
• 1x 8 1/2x 11" map
• 1 Game Reference card
• 12 p. illustrated color rules booklet with historical commentary & bibliography.
• 54" 9/16" game pieces, representing combat units and status markers

The game is also available on Cyberboard

Deluxe Honey Springs, with die cut counters, an 11x17 map and tabloid printed rules, in a folio folder, is available from the publisher.

link.value: Battles of the American Civil War

item.description:
Battle of Gettysburg is a two player brigade level game depicting the largest battle of the American Civil War.

Battle of Gettysburg recreates specific portions of the battle as game scenarios, using historical units and arrival times, and also includes various alternative history options.

Playing times: MacPherson's Ridge (July 1) 60-120 minutes; Longstreet's Attack (July 2), Pickett's Charge (July 3), Meades' Counterattack (alt-history July 4) 120-180 minutes.

Battle Games (historical & alt-history) 6 to 12 hours, depending on start date and time. All Battle Games have sudden death conditions that can end the battle whenever fulfilled.

Solitaire friendly

Components:


 22"x25" Game Map 
 324 9/16" pieces, representing historical combat units and unit or formation status markers. 
 4 Setup Cards, 2 Order of Appearance Cards and a Game Reference card for each player. 
 24 page color booklet of rules, play illustrations and detailed historical commentary. 
 1 Six-sided Die

link.value: Battles of the American Civil War

item.description:
'Grant's Early Battles is a collection of games about Ulysses S. Grant's first experience of command. Three battles are covered - Belmont, Fort Donelson and Shiloh. Belmont, and the single day scenarios of Fort Donelson and Shiloh can be played in two to four hours. The two larger battles also have multi-day actions which make for a challenging 6 to 8 hour games. Various alternative history options are included.

Components:

 Three 11"x17" Game Maps (one for each battle) 
 432 9/16" pieces, representing historical combat units and unit or formation status markers. 
 Two Game Reference cards for each player 
 28 page color booklet of rules, play illustrations and detailed historical commentary. 
 1 Six-sided Die

link.value: Battles of the American Civil War

item.description:
Across the Wide Missouri is a collection of three Civil War battles in Missouri and Arkansas - Wilson's Creek, Pea Ridge and Prairie Grove. Prairie Grove and Wilson's Creek can be played in three to four hours. Pea Ridge is a two day battle with hidden initial deployments, and can take up to 8 hours. Various alternative history options are included.

Wilson's Creek and Prairie Grove are solitaire friendly. Pea Ridge requires hidden units and maneuver, so some sort of randomized battle plan is needed. Multiple personality disorder or a cooperative friend a plus.

Components:
One 11"x17" Map (Wilson's Creek); One 12"x18" Map (Prairie Grove), One 17"x22" Map (Pea Ridge) 
432 9/16" pieces, representing historical combat units and unit or formation status markers. 
One Game Reference card for each player with Terrain Effects and Combat Results Charts 
28 page color booklet of rules, play illustrations and detailed historical commentary. 
1 Six-sided Die

Currently Shipping (15 September 2007)

link.value: Battles of the American Civil War

item.description:
This Trivial Pursuit edition is dedicated to the best soccer club in XX century (FIFA award)

The mechanics of the game are similar to other Trivial Pursuit games, but questions are about history and players of Real Madrid.

The game is in Spanish and the components in the box are:

 Game Board
 1 die
 450 Question & Answer Cards
 4 Player pieces

Magical energies await exploitation from you and your fellow wizards and the apprentices you each control. Cast the rune stones to find where you may put your apprentices to work. Use them to build towers to gain powers, bonuses and points. Use them to destroy opponents’ towers. Or build your towers next to others to increase their value. Use the special abilities your towers give you to protect yourself, attack others, gain points at the end of the game.
 Will you focus on building close together to make a strong base worth a lot of points, spread your towers around to win influence across the land, or focus on destroying competitors’ towers with your awesome army of apprentices?
 The wizard that has gained the most power and influence at the end will be the Mage with the Most, the Sorcerer Supreme, and the Mightiest Magician.

name.value: Guerra a Muerte: Latin America's "War to the Death" (1810-1824)

item.description:
Against the Odds magazine #23

Americans seldom notice the enormous changes that the Napoleonic Wars caused to the Western Hemisphere...things far larger and with much greater effects than our own War of 1812.

The Louisiana Purchase really started it, as Napoleon sold Jefferson a large block of land that really "belonged" to Spain. In shifting their forces to try and limit American expansion, the Spanish-loyal authorities opened the door to losing the remainder of two continents. Guerra a Muerte depicts the 14 year struggle that saw Spain's possessions in the hemisphere change from "almost everything not U.S." to "Cuba and Hispanola."

As in the American Revolution, the local population could be divided into "patriots/revolutionaries" on one side, "loyalists/Royalists" on the other, and a huge middle block of those who wished to stay out of battle--over which both sides exerted tremendous pressure, making these episodes as bitter as a period in history. The game title means, "War to the Death," and comes from a proclamation Simon Bolivar made to all Spaniards in Venezuela--"support us or else."

Warfare took place from the remote northern border with America to the tip of the continent now shared by Chile and Argentina. Progress ebbed and flowed, with territories changing hands several times and the intensity and size of battles slowly escalating.

The overall war is a fascinating struggle of varied elements, from Spanish and "Royalist" troops to formed patriot units, militias, armed mobs, Indians, and mercenaries. Actions include slave revolts, naval assaults, guerilla war, battles with a hostile environment, and the interplay of politics with economics...all depicted and intermeshed to affect overall play as they affected real events. The game offers a map from "New Spain" to "Rio de la Plata," with area movement, one-year turns, and 280 half-inch counters.

Guerra a Muerte offers a chance to understand a hardly-heard-of period of Western history, the effects of which are still with us today.

A playaid sheet with additional optional rules are organized into one sheet and included on issue #27.

item.description: Mixture of Rummy and Domino. 72 tiles and 12 wild tiles facedown. On each tile is a letter and a number. Draw a tile , try to lay it out in sets (3 of a kind etc)where either the number or the letter is increasing. You can arrange all tiles from all players new, But beware of the hourglass, if time runs out any tile which is not alid down valid goes to your hand. First player without tiles wins

This game uses 24 checkers with 12 in each color and a checker board or a 6 by 6 grid as the game only uses the middle 36 squares of a typical 8 by 8 checker board. Each player places his checkers in the back row of his side of the board. The game turns alternate between the two players. The number of checkers in a stack determines the distance that a stack may move. Moves can be made in any of the eight corresponding directions and cannot be blocked by stacks situated in the path of the move. All moves are done in a straight line unless the move would extend through 6 by 6 grid formation, in which case the move is reflected by the edge of the 6 by 6 grid like a mirror. A stack belongs to the player whose piece is on top. It might be noted that the arrangement and order of the pieces within a stack can never be altered except by continued stacking. Captured stacks always remain on the board and become part of the stack must be included in the count for the new movement distance. A player may use his turn to place a stack on top of another one of his own stacks. During a turn a player has the option of moving one of his stacks or only its top portion which may include any number of pieces and may leave behind a stack also composed of any number of pieces. The height of the new divided stack determines the new movement distance.

In 2005, the "Too-Tall Rule" or variant was introduced. This rule states that at the beginning of a turn that any player's stacks taller than four pieces must be divided. Failure to comply with this rule causes a player to lose a turn.

The game can be classified as a variant of Sid Sackson's Focus.

http://www.stevecobb.com/Death%20Stacks%20--%20game%20instructions.htm

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_Stacks

name.value: Bowles's Geographical Game of Europe, In a New, complete, and elegant Tour through the different Kingdoms, States, Cities, &c. of Europe: Designed by Dr. NUGENT

item.description:
This game is believed to be the first or one of the first known games in the English-speaking world to be attributed to an individual designer.

It was first published by Carrington Bowles, a British publisher of hand-tinted, cloth-backed maps. This game reconfigured a map of Europe to provide a game rather than a reference. It's a straightforward track game. The game uses a teetotum, a spinning top with numbered sides, as dice were viewed as gambling instruments that would not be permitted in respectable households. The players begin and end in London, and many spaces advance players or transport them to other portions of the board. For example, a playing piece that lands on Hanover "shall by order of Ye King of Great Britain who is Elector, be conducted to ... Gibraltar to visit his countrymen who keep garrison there" while the playing piece that lands on "Rome for kissing ye Pope's Toe shall be banished for his folly to ... the cold island of Iceland and miss three turns".

http://www.escapistmagazine.com/issue/42/13

This is a curling game which you can play on any flat surface, and it takes just seconds to set up.
It's a dexterity game that need a very good feeling so you don't push the stones to far.
A sociable and entertaining game which includes competitive elements.

The game is based around placing symbol cards so that either their colour or shape match their neighbours. The game area is restricted to an 8 by 8 card limit.

Symbotica can be played in four different ways: the Standard Game, the Simple Game, Five Card Symbotica and the one player Symbotica Challenge.

The aim of the Standard, Simple and Five Card Symbotica games is to score the maximum number of points. Points are scored based on the placing of the cards. In order to cater for different age groups, the scoring is either based on addition or multiplication.

The one player Symbotica Challenge consists of trying to get as close as possible to the full grid of 64 cards using the same placement rules as the other games but without any scoring.

The game appeals to a wide range of ages from children learning simple pattern matching, addition or multiplication right up to those adults who want to keep their mind fit.

Home Page: http://www.symbotica.com/

This is a children's game for 2 to 4 players Ages 5 - 12.

This is believed to be the first Underdog board game as it was released in 1964, the year that the animated series voiced by Wally Cox first appeared on NBC.

This is a humorous game of give and take in which the players try not to become the Underdog. The game has all the familiar cartoon characters. When a playing piece stops on a space, the player draws a card. If the card matches the character on the space, the player keeps the card. If the playing piece lands on one of the bright yellow Underdog spaces, the player takes a card from each player. The game comes with a gameboard, four wooden playing pieces, die, and 24 cards.

This is a children's game for those Ages 3 - 6.

This variation of the game Bingo involves picture puzzles of cartoon characters Dinky Duck, Goose and Gander, Heckle and Jeckle, and Mighty Mouse.

In this game, warriors and wizards are fighting against each other. These characters are... barcodes !

The game consists in an electronic device with a barcode scanner included, and a set of cards representing heroes, enemies and equipments. There's also a few blank cards that you can use to create your own characters with any barcode found on common products.

Game description from the publisher:

An infectiously fun non-collectible card game for 2-4 players, Infernal Contraption pits goblin mechanics against each other in a race to assemble often-backfiring, nigh-uncontrollable magical machines. Through the strategic placement of arcane components like arcantric funnels, chthonic grinders, and entropic processors, these bodgers risk life and limb to overcome the competition with the ultimate Infernal Contraption.

The second edition of Infernal Contraption includes cards from the Sabotage! expansion and a special promo card for the Bodgers Game Heap.

Infernal Contraption: Zombiphage Cannon Promo Card

item.description: This children's game for Ages 7 - 12 was based upon a Saturday morning NBC cartoon show. The game includes four Hector playing pieces and a Cannon-type bowling device.

Combat Moonbase is a set of rules for tactical spaceship combat using miniatures (1/400 scale, according to the rules). Rules are provided (in Attack Wargaming's inimitable style) for lasers, missiles, plasma torpedoes, ECM, chaff, and landing and taking off from planets.

Information is provided for three types of ships, two from the Eastern Coalition and Western Alliance (who are fighting over the titular moonbase) and one from the alien Thook. It is not clear if this background is shared with any other Attack Wargaming games.

The game's arch-shaped track is designed to look like a pinball game. There are only 21 game track spaces. The game uses a die instead of a spinner and has a metal piece with a spring that helps determine extra scoring by shooting the die along the inside of the arch boundary. Where the die lands determines the extra scoring. The movement track has places with sayings such as "stubs toe -- go back 3 spaces," "steps on cat -- go back 2 spaces," "trips on shoe lace -- go back 3 spaces," and "sees bully -- go back 4 spaces."

The game uses a different artistic style for the inside game and the box exterior.

Election '68 (CreaTek, 1967) does an excellent job of featuring the early candidates in caricature form on cards, and shows the probable front runners for each party on the cover: Richard Nixon for the Republicans; Robert Kennedy for the Democrats with Lyndon Johnson who had decided to not seek re-election "presiding" over both.

name.value: Presidential Election Game: Goldwater For President

item.description:
from notes from Tony and Theresa Game Wardens

This single, large piece of cardboard comprises the entirety of the Presidential Election Game: Goldwater For President (Kom-Pak, 1964).

One unusual feature of this game is that all pieces are furnished as cutout parts, including the six-sided die. Another noteworthy feature is the small Barry Goldwater circle, which presumably was intended to fill the empty circle on the board reserved for the 36th President. This game is marked, "Approved by the Republican Nat'l Committee."

On the 12 April 1861 the Confederate army bombs Fort Sumter, starting the American Civil War. On the 9 April 1865, General Lee and his Confederate army surrender to General Grant at Appomattox, ending four years of war. This game recreates the whole war (translation from box cover).

This game was published as part of the "second wave" of NAC´s wargames in 1983. Rules were quite easy to understand, as most of NAC´s titles until that date. There were only three types of counters in each band: generals, regular infantry and volunteers, plus conquest markers.

Contents were:
-64x80 cms. mapboard
-counters
-2 plastic trays for the counters
-1 special die (without "1" and "6")
-Rulebook

Number of players: 2-4 (but ideally 2)
Playing time: 180 min. approx.
Difficulty: easy

item.description:
Betsy Ross and the Flag is a game from Transogram that is advertized on its cover as a "Thrilling Historical Game" and as being part of the Landmark Games Series. Ages 9 and up

Each player is Betsy Ross carrying a sewing basket with which to "sew" the original flag. Players obtain 13 flag pieces by visiting the Town Hall in each of the 13 Colonial States. When the flag is completed, the player races to deliver it to the Flag Committee. The first player to enter the blue circle and greet the Flag Committee with a completed flag wins the game.

Da Li Shui Shou literally means 'strong sailor' but the graphics used in the game clearly show the strong sailor to be none other than Popeye, the cartoon character. 
The players have a choice of being Popeye, Olive or Bluto and the object of the game is to get all your pieces from the start to the finish. Along the way, there are spaces with various instructions to follow.
This curious Chinese roll-and-move game comes on a key chain. The tiny box holds the 12 pieces (four for each player), a little teetotum and a small folded paper board.

This children's game was based upon a cartoon segment of Hanna-Barbera's The Magilla Gorilla Show where Ricochet Rabbit worked as a Western sheriff in Hoop n' Holler along with his deputy Droop-A-Long Coyote. The game includes
a game board with a cloverleaf-shaped track, a movement spinner, and mad man cards.

This children's combat town game for Ages 8 - 15 was based upon the 1960s short-lived television series written by Star Trek creator Gene Roddenberry. The television show was a Marine Corps drama set at Camp Pendleton. The game comes with a game board, a small campaign map, a set of cards, spinners, and small cardboard tanks and riflemen.

Duchove, Demoni a Draci or Ghosts, Demons and Dragons is a Talisman-esque game of rolling and movement around a fantasy landscape.

Billed as a "Heroicka Fantasy" (Heroic Fantasy) game, it is only available in the Czech Republic.

Cards had to be cut out prior to play and the board consists of four glossy paper parts.

item.description:
Significantly different from the celebrated bookshelf title, this Jati is a solo dexterity game where a player must use a magnet to guide a piece through a maze; in a sense, a bizarre relative of Polarity and Labyrinth.

From the game box:
"Jati, the fascinating action Puzzler, will challenge your skill as it tests your cool. All you do is maneuver the magnet around the Jati maze. Sounds easy - but, here's the catch - you can't touch the magnet! All maneuvering must be done with the magnetic wand. Come too close to the magnet with the wand and - you've had it. The magnet either plunges over the edge or reverses itself and leaps toward the wand. Only a dazzling display of dexterity on your part will maneuver the magnet around the Jati maze and into the center. So, test your skill and dexterity; see if you're a novice or a Jati Master, and score yourself accordingly. As a novice, you'll only score 25 points. To be a JATI Master, you'll have to maneuver the magnet in printed side up - no easy feat! For superb skill, the Jati Master scores 100 points. What if you get the magnet in upside down, you ask. Well, then you're only an advanced Jati player; score 75 points and keep practicing.

Not to be confused with:
Jati, a tile laying game

Who killed Gloria Don? The game and the story begins with the discovery of the body and ends with the question: Who was the murderer? Each player acts as Chief of the Homicide Squad and as each new fact is unearthed he/she must choose the next step to take in his/her investigation. In doing so he may win money from his fellow investigators or he may lose to them, sometimes Heavily.

The game comes with paper money, some of which is distributed to the players, and a sheet which tells the background of the crime. The background is either read to ones self or read out loud to the entire group. Then the first page of the crime case is read. On the reverse of each case players will find 10 possible courses of action that he/she as investigator may take. After carefully considering all the given facts and without consulting any other player each investigator checks the two courses of action that he/she feels should now be taken.

After all players have decided on their particular course of actions a blue sheet is read which gives both benefits and penalties to each player depending on what decisions they have made. If both of the choices that an investigator makes are good the player will collect money from the kitty, if both are bad ones the player will pay into the kitty, if one is good and one is bad there will be a net plus/minus total which will create a small gain or loss.

Now the next page of the crime is read and the another set of 10 possible actions will be given from which each player can choose two courses of action. This continues until final evidence is presented and each player will be asked "Who Killed Gloria Don? Being correct pays off, being wrong costs you money. At the end of the game all players who have more money than what they started with sort of win with the player with the most money being the overall winner of the game. Many cases were available !

From the box: TREK appeals to the wanderlust inherent in most Americans -- to "hit the road" and find out what lies over the hill or around the next bend; to see how the other fellow lives; and to just get away from it all.

To start the play, the players agree first on the TREK. It will usually start from the home town. It can end anywhere. If you live in the north, you may want to go to Florida and back. If you live in the east, you may want to go to the west coast and back. The maps provided cover the entire United States on a scale so large that all but the smallest towns are shown. They are the latest and most accurate maps that Rand McNally can provide.

Each may follow a different route or all may follow the same route, but success may depend on who selects the shortest and fastest route.

The first player spins the arrow on the spinning board at least on complete revolution and proceeds as directed, sticking his pin/auto into the map to mark his position.

Delays, accidents, and detours affect only the player involved. Other players proceed according to their own directions as indicated by the luck of the spin.

Really, directions are hardly necessary. The game is so like a real TREK that once you get into the spirit of the thing and use the imagination, you will meet the emergencies as they arise.

In the game Sombrero players try to get their marbles through a maze and into the precariously balanced orange plastic sombrero. The upper surface called the sombrero had a circular maze that was balanced on a spring on a base. The players placed marbles on the indentations around the circular edge to tilt the sombrero in order to move another marbles through the maze to the center.

item.description: This is believed to be a very rare and unusual "historical" game. The box cover with beautiful artwork states that it is "Fun For All Ages." The players use replica Spanish galleons to sail the Caribbean in a race for island strongholds and pirate gold. The game states that the treasure locations are based upon historical facts.

This game is based upon the 1968-1970 CBS western television series named Lancer, a darker version of the more successful television show Bonanza.

Some of the accessories include a game board, dice, four cardboard playing figures with plastic bases, a plastic "bad man" figure, a deck of reward cards, and a pack of reward money.

Pick a card and choose the subject that seems funniest to you. Can you come up with a funny thing to say about the subject? an original joke my win you three points. Having trouble? Simply turn the card over and a joke is prepared for you. Can you read it like a pro and produce laughter from the audience? A successful reading can earn you two points.

Included are blue cards with over 300 original jokes and premises of all types, 180 counting chips, instructions, a 32-page book - "How to Produce Laughter" by David Challenge, and one plastic banana.

THIS GAME CONTAINS COMEDY FOR GROWN-UPS
Although the included jokes meet the decency standards of late-night network TV, parental guidance is suggested for younger players.

You have never played a bingo game like this before. To play, roll the bingo dice and cover the space shown on the dice if you answer a trivia question correctly. But, if your answer is incorrect, you must re-roll the dice and uncover the space shown. The question can always be passed to the next player without penalty, but then your opponent may get the answer right and score a bingo before you do. Whoever scores bingo first, wins the game.

item.description: In the 1920s and 30s, many cities in the US witnessed gang wars in the streets. This game simulates the struggle for the control of the city. The objective is to own the most businesses, either by buying them or by stealing them from another player.

This game based upon the Kennedy assassination is based on the game Candyland. The four characters include Johnny, Jackie, Oswald, and Ruby. The board game artwork is by Roy Tompkins. It is stated that the average playing time is only 6 seconds!

Polish non-collectible card game originally printed in Portal magazine (issue 4/2000). The aim of the game is to build the best village while disturbing other administrator's efforts. Cards concern issues such as bureaucracy, religious fundamentalism, provincional mentality and socialist heritage.

Available as public domain since 2006.

item.description: This is an adaptation of the lawn game Bocce or Lawn Bowling as a tabletop coin Flicking Game for the piecepack. Plays best with 2, 4 or 8 players in two teams. This game requires a seamless smooth playing surface of about 24x48 inches.
This is an adaptation of the lawn game Nine-wicket Croquet as a tabletop coin Flicking Game for the piecepack. This game requires a seamless smooth-surface table of at least 3x5 feet.

This is an adaptation of the game disc golf as a tabletop coin Flicking Game for the piecepack. It provides for a randomly set up course and does not require a library of pre-designed holes. It also allows for solitaire play. This game plays best on a smooth seamless surface table that allows flicked coins to easily slide the length of the table. The game requires a table of at least 8 square feet in area, but the shape of the table doesn't matter.

This is a two layer solitaire sliding block puzzle, like an expanded version of the classic 15-puzzle, designed for the piecepack. The player is required to rearrange two different sets of values simultaneously, that move in different but related ways.

Based on the Superman Returns movie.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The Special Kryptonite Card. When the Kryptonite card is played each of the other players, in turn, must play a green or a wild card from their hand. The Kryptonite card may also be used as a wild card.

At the beginning the clock is set for 12 o'clock. The pawn stands at the field with the glassy shoes.

Each player takes a set of cards and lays them with un-bewitched side open at the table. The player throws the die and draws the pawn. Is the final field a good fairy he is allowed to bewitch one of his cards. He turns it so that the bewitched side is open. Is it an evil fairy one bewitched card has to be turn to the other side. The player whose cards with ball dress, a coach, horses, coachman and prince are open in front of him wins.

From the back of the box:
Take your turn to spin the spinner and see what it says for you to do. Magic the storycards with the Fairy Godmother; Unmagic the storycards with the Nasty Stepsisters. Win the heart of the Handsome Prince, or move the clock forward three hours, but beware!!! ... tick, tock, tick, tock... when midnight comes, you must Unmagic all your storycards.

A card containing a letter is turned over. The active player proposes a word starting with this letter then, if he wishes it, turns over a new card and must propose a new word starting with the first turned over letter and containing the new letter. He proceeds, as long as he feels able to include the next letter.
Of course, if you cannot find a word containing all the letters, you do not have to turn a new card over.
If the active player decides to stop, the other players can try to do better while drawing a new letter at their turn...

When you are the last to propose a word, you gain all cards including the same symbol. When the game ends, the player who has the most cards is declared the Winner.

item.description:
It is a simulation of the sport Football (or 'Soccer' for those countries with their own codes of Football), and uses the dexterity technique - 'Flicking'. 
The one page rules are comprehensive and include fouls, corner throws and free kicks.
You must score three goals to win.
Apparently this is the very first game designed for the piecepack.

Dipole, played with a Checkers set, begins with two stacks of checkers: a stack of 12 white checkers in White's nearest row, and likewise for Black. A stack, or a portion of a stack, is moved a distance equal to the number of checkers in the moved stack. So a three-stack, for example, can be moved a distance of three squares. Non-capturing moves must be made forward or diagonally forward. Capturing moves can be made in any of eight directions. A stack can capture only equal size or smaller stacks.

To win, all of your opponent's checkers must be removed from the board.

Draws cannot occur in Dipole.

item.description:
Magical Tower is a game in the Wooden Balance Game series by Daiso, the Japanese 100-yen store chain. The game is cheap but has nice wooden components. It bears a striking resemblance to Villa Paletti.

The game has plain cuboid wooden pillars and colourful flat semi-circular and arc-like pieces. Players take turn to use the pieces to build a tower-like structure and the player who causes the tower to tumble loses.

Flower Table is a game in the Wooden Balance Game series by Daiso, the Japanese 100-yen shop chain. These games may be cheap but they do have nice production values and are made of wood.

The game consists of a flower-like board that is balanced precariously on a stand in the shape of a truncated pyramid. The board is divided into petal-like segments, each with a blue, red or yellow spot. There are several little cubes and a die with a blue, red or yellow spot on its sides. Each player rolls the die and has to place a cube on a petal segment with the corresponding coloured spot. The player who causes the flower table to topple loses.

This is essentially the same game as the later and much more popular game Loopin' Louie. However, it appears that this game pre-dates Loopin' Louie by almost 25 years!

The front of the box proclaims, "Up and down and around the old plane goes. Where she hits nobody knows."

The game was manufactured by Marx Games which appears to be a division of Marx Toys as the two companies used a similar font in their logos.

The game uses thick horizontal discs instead of thinner vertically placed discs used in Loopin' Louie. The discs appear to be very similar to the game pieces for the more popular game Trivial Pursuit with the interior of these discs divided into four sections instead of six.

item.description:
This game is based upon a young Angela Cartwight from the television show "Make Room For Daddy" which was later known as "The Danny Thomas Show." Angela Cartwight is also famous for appearing in the television show "Lost in Space" and the film "The Sound of Music."

The game box has a photo of her on the cover from around the age 7 or 8. The game comes with four game markers and four Angela picture cards, a spinner, and lots of vinyl buttons and bows used as game pieces.

"Who will be the first to pick and match Angela's Magic Battons 'N Bows?"

Polykatastimata (ΠολυκαταστÎ®ματα:Greek word for "shopping malls"),is a game published by Nilco S.A. (importer and translator of many MB games in Greece)back in 1990. The designer credits unfortunately are not mentioned on the box.

The game is similar to the classic board game, Monopoly but instead of properties and buildings,you have to deal with shopping malls (true firms in Athens of 80s -90s)and their shares.There are some other differences like players draw "Order cards" each turn and resolve immediately their effect,two players can merge their fortunes and make common decisions for the rest of the game or you can take a bank loan.

item.description:
From the box:

Phase 10 UpSets, the vertical rummy game!

The challenging and exciting twists of the popular card game go 3-D! Try to complete each of the 10 specific phases on the vertical game grid but watch out for the upset. As you get close to winning, one of your opponents can upset you and the grid with one single tile and more than your hopes will come crashing down.

Playing grid,
4 tile holders,
Dice and 61 tiles.

Ages 5 and up

è¥¿ç“œæ£‹ (xÄ« guÄ qíÌ), or Watermelon Game, has been described as a traditional folk game from Hangzhou for children. The set I have was purchased from a toy shop in Shanghai.

Xi Gua Qi is played on a board that vaguely resembles a watermelon. It is a game of abstract strategy and the object is to capture the opponent's pieces by immobilization. Each player starts with six pieces and moves them from intersection to intersection on the board. If you succeed in surrounding an opponent's piece with your own pieces, it is removed from the board. The winner is the player who reduces his opponent to less than two pieces.

The game is available as computer software by Locke Corp for the pocket PC.

In this game of manual dexterity, players attempt to bat a "ball" into scoring locations on a long flat wooden board that can be between 4 to 6 feet long! The game resembles a crude pinball machine. The game also comes with a score pad, a bell, and scoring devices. The box cover states that from 1 to 9 players can play on a team.

ABC Bingo Games help kids acquire valuable pre-reading skills - like alphabet and sound-letter recognition - while they play a fun game.
Players learn to identify, pronounce, and discuss dozens of words as they move their animal playing pieces along the game board. Unlike traditional bingo, ABC Bingo Games do not use a bingo caller. Instead, when players land on a game-board square, they identify the square's animal, person, or object illustration; state the first letter of the word; and, if it's on their alphabet bingo mat, cover the letter with a bingo chip. Each ABC Bingo Game also includes an illustrated Word list for extra practice or review.

item.description:
In addition to being a normal deck of cards, each card pictures av device from a James Bond movie (like the Q boat from "The world is not enough", or the Marine Scooter from "Thunderball") or James Bond himself (Sean Connery, George Lazenby, Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton, Pierce Brosnan).

Each card also denotes unique values for six variables for the creature on the photo (Damage, Protection, Ingenuity, Stealth, Technology and Multi-purpose). Each player play their top card, and the starting player selects variable. The player with highest value wins the card and is the next rounds starter.

The game separates from other similar card games by having a secret message (e.g. name of next mission card) on the back of every Bond-card, only visible when seen trough a red plastic lens, which goes with the game.

Game number 5370 from Eberhard Faber, this game
"Combin(es) the skill of both chess and checkers with a new and tantalizing element of chance."
The board is an elongated checkerboard of two distinct colouring patterns, with several zones added in the centre and some out-of-bounds zones. Each player is provided with 10 pawns, which have movement rules similar to bishops in chess. An element of chance is introduced through dice rolling as well.

The box title is TAK TICS, while the Rule Book is labeled TAC TIKS

name.value: Monopoly van Dam tot Dom editie

item.description:
This Version of Monopoly offers the well known game play. But instead of paper money, credit cards a used. Every player has its own card, a small card reading computer resolves all payments.

The streets in this version are named after streets and places in Berlin. Monopoly Banking was the best-selling boardgame in Germany in 2006.
